request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Health Information
Hospital main line or Privacy Officer direct line

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient must download a generic Authorization for Release of Health Information form (image-only scan), print it, fill it out by hand listing themselves as the recipient, and contact the hospital to learn how to submit it.

red_flags: Social Security Number field prominently included alongside patient identifiers — unnecessary for records release and creates identity theft risk
No submission instructions on the form — no mailing address, fax number, or email for submitting the completed authorization
Form revision date is January 2014 (over a decade old); scanned in 2016, uploaded in 2019
bright_spots: Spanish-language version of the authorization form available on the same Resources page — notable for a small rural critical access hospital
Granular 14-item record-type checklist gives patients control over which specific records are released
Very low per-page copy fee ($0.03/page) well within HIPAA limits
NPP names a specific Privacy Officer (Courtney Schmelzle) with direct phone and email contact

findability.rationale: Level 4: Form was easy to find via site navigation (2 clicks from homepage) and site-scoped search; Resources page labels the link clearly, though general filetype:pdf searches did not surface it directly.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Image-only scan with zero fillable fields and no text layer; patient must print, handwrite all fields, and contact the hospital to determine submission method — a primarily paper workflow.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Logical field sequence and reasonably clear legal language, but undermined by dense paragraph text without visual breaks, staff-facing cost worksheet included as page 2, pagination errors, and dated typewriter-style formatting.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form by listing themselves as recipient, but the form was not designed for patient self-access — it lacks right-of-access language, requires naming a recipient and purpose as if for third-party disclosure, and provides no guidance for patients requesting their own records.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Fees are reasonable and no notarization required, but SSN collection goes beyond what is legally necessary, no right-of-access language is included, and the lack of submission instructions creates an implicit barrier that may delay patient requests.

overall.summary: Nemaha Valley Community Hospital's records request process is easy to find but hampered by a decade-old image-only scan form, a generic third-party authorization design with no patient access differentiation, an unnecessary SSN field, and missing submission instructions.
